etymologies: Old English ēare, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch oor and German Ohr, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin auris and Greek ous

definitions: the organ of hearing and balance in humans and other vertebrates, especially the external part of this.

notes.text: The ear of a mammal is composed of three parts. The outer or external ear consists of a fleshy external flap and a tube leading to the eardrum or tympanum. The middle ear is an air-filled cavity connected to the throat, containing three small linked bones that transmit vibrations from the eardrum to the inner ear. The inner ear is a complex fluid-filled labyrinth including the spiral cochlea (where vibrations are converted to nerve impulses) and the three semicircular canals (forming the organ of balance). The ears of other vertebrates are broadly similar

shortDefinitions: organ of hearing and balance in humans and other vertebrates

definitions: an organ sensitive to sound in other animals.
shortDefinitions: organ sensitive to sound in other animals

definitions: an ability to recognize, appreciate, and reproduce sounds, especially music or language
used to refer to a person's willingness to listen and pay attention to something

examples.text: she offers a sympathetic ear to worried pet owners

shortDefinitions: used to refer to person's willingness to listen to others

definitions: an ear-shaped thing, especially the handle of a jug.

phrases.text: have an ear to the ground
have something coming out of one's ears
in one ear and out the other

etymologies: Old English ēar, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch aar and German Ähre

definitions: the seed-bearing head or spike of a cereal plant.
shortDefinitions: seed-bearing head or spike of cereal plant
